#TuesdayTip... Six small ways to ensure your child feels loved and heard.

1. Spend some uninterrupted time together as a family every day.

2. Go beyond generic questions such as how was school and strike up conversations about their passions and what they're currently interested in.

3. Show your love by showing your affection. You can give them a hug before bed, or if a party doesn't like hugging, create your own special handshake or dance.

4. Become passionate about their interest. Listen to their new favorite songs, build Legos, play Fortnite, or anything else that helps them feel supported.

5. Create simple, fun traditions by creating unique moments that happen once a month. Nothing fancy or expensive. It can be as simple as going fishing in a park, eating ice cream after school, or going to a library and picking up new books.

6. Allow room for self-expression.

Living and learning at home can be stressful for students of all ages. Providing opportunities to move independently and together as a family unit is vital to your students' health and will help them remain active and focused while learning from home. During a long stretch of remote learning, tell your students to take a 10-minute break and engage in activities of their choice, such as running, playing basketball, or playing tag as a family. An item to consider is that some people can focus better on tasks when they're standing, so consider having their computer or tablet raised so that they can learn while they stand.

#TuesdayTip...Create a conducive learning environment

Picking a place in your home for your child to learn might not be the easiest thing to achieve. You do not want them to be too isolated that you cannot check up on them or in an environment that is too loud. Picking the optimal place in your home that is dedicated to school-focused activities will be beneficial to your child's success. When deciding where to set them up, make sure they're not located in an area where they spend most of their free time when they're home. You want to pick an area that is quiet, free from distractions, and has good lighting. Also, have a conversation with them to discover how they like to learn. Do they want music on or off? Do they want to work outside or indoors? An open dialogue will help create an optimal environment for the way they learn, and one that is free from distractions.

#WellnessWednesday... Get active for a happy and healthy brain!

Most of us are familiar with the benefits of being physically active, but did you know that regular exercise helps with brain health and cognition? It's true! Many studies have discovered that regular exercise improves memory and thinking - direct and indirect. Directly, being active reduces insulin resistance, reduces inflammation, and stimulates the release of growth factors. Indirectly, exercise helps to improve mood and sleep and reduces stress and anxiety. In school, being regularly active is associated with higher grades and test scores, and it has been proven to increase concentration and attention. However, you like to be active whether it's running or swimming as long as you exercise regularly, you will have a happy and healthy brain.

Plan your work and work your plan.

Creating a consistent schedule for schoolwork that helps to identify to-do items for each day will give you the opportunity to plan your workday while also providing a smoother transition in and out of school for your student. Your plan can relieve stress for everyone involved. Each Sunday, schedule 15 minutes to check in with your child about their plans and help them create a written schedule for their upcoming week broken up by each day. While developing this list, you can teach them how to prioritize specific items to achieve their goals, tasks, and deadlines, similar to what you do at work. When your child sees a clear and defined representation of what is expected from them through the week, it will help them better understand that just because you're at home doesn't mean there is no work to be done.

Family meals were once a tradition in every household, but in recent years families have gotten out of the habit of eating together. It is beneficial for everyone to eat at least one meal together a day for several physical, emotional, mental, and social benefits. Dinner is an excellent opportunity to gather as a family to talk about each other's day while sharing a meal.

It's Juneteenth! The oldest nationally celebrated commemoration of the ending of slavery in the United States. On June 19, 1865, Major General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas, with Union soldiers with news that the Civil War had ended and that the enslaved were now free - more than two and a half years after President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation.

The Emancipation Proclamation had little impact in Texas due to minimal Union Troops in the state enforcing the President's proclamation and executive order. However, after General Lee surrendered in 1865, and the arrival of Major General Gordon Granger Texas became strong enough to enforce the proclamation and overcome the resistance.

Tis a new year and New Years' mean resolutions! Each year so many of us make all these promises that we don't keep after just a few days or weeks. But it goes beyond yearly resolutions. How many promises to we make to ourselves and others and we don't keep? Do promises and commitments mean nothing these days? We definitely think so. That's why it's important we help grow kids that keep promises to become adults who stick to their commitments.

One way to do this is before committing to anything, ask yourself "is this something I can really do?" While it is important that your kids make goals that will stretch them, it is equally important that their goals and promises are realistic so that they can actually achieve them.

One way to help make promises realistic is by establishing time parameters. When they have a specific timeline they will stay focused and not likely to forget their goal after a month or two. They‚Äôll also be more motivated to continue the task after the excitement wears down - if the promise is actually doable. #TuesdayTip

#TuesdayTip... Engineering shapes the world around us.

Engineering is defined as the use of scientific principles to design and build machines, structures, and other items, including bridges, roads, vehicles, and buildings. This may seem like something that, if you're not into those kinds of things, is hard to help you child get into. But it's really not. Because engineering is a relatively broad field there are many different approaches and ways you can help spark an interest.

Lego's and building blocks are a great example for the structural aspect of things. Do you like to fix things? Spending time showing them how each part comes together (and apart) and work as a whole is another option. The main idea to build an understanding and maybe a passion for how things work and how they are being used today so that maybe they can use those things to build the innovations of tomorrow.

#WellnessWednesday... Get Moving! It's good for your bones.

Did you know that inactivity can impact bone health? It's true. Part of being a child means growing, literally. As much as 36 percent of the human skeleton is formed in girls ages 10 to 14 and boys ages 12 to 16 and our bones are particularly responsive to physical activity. Kids who are less active had weaker bones. In other words, those who are sitting around gaming, using technology or just being lazy are not loading their bones in ways that promote bone strength, according to a study. Even short bursts of activity such as dancing, skipping, or chasing the dog can have a positive impact on bone health.

#TuesdayTip.... Reading beyond Books?

Reading is about comprehension. It builds visualization, thinking and language abilities but it doesn't always have to be words on paper (although those are highly recommended). Audio books are a great addition to traditional reading. They help children build up aural comprehension while getting lost in the story they are hearing, similarly when you read to them. You can listen to them in the car, or turn off the TV and have the family listen to them together. Maybe try audio books for books they've already read. Does the story seem different this time around?

Additionally, if you discover that your child is having trouble with reading, he or she may have a learning disability. 80% of children with a learning disability have difficulty with basic reading and language. Audio books can be a good tool to help build confidence while improving comprehension.

It's Honesty Day! Teaching Honesty is something that must be encouraged at home and in the classroom. Lying 'innocently enough' starts off as stories crafted by the wild imagination of kids combined with the desire to not get into trouble but can get worse if left unchecked. We have to show kids to be respectful of themselves and others but being honest, even in the smallest of circumstances. Try rewarding honesty more as this provides positive reinforcement to encourage continued honesty rather than striving to becoming better liars.

Learning to be an honest person is something children develop over time and it is our responsibility to guide them towards the honest path. üòä #TuesdayTip
